Cramer made a key discovery related to Alzheimer's that could mean an old cancer drug, Bexarotene, could have benefits in the brain disease. She co-founded a biotechnology company, Rexceptor, to commercialize the work. Two clinical trials are ongoing, and others have shown that the same compound may have efficacy in Parkinson's and epilepsy -- at least in mice. She's now working at Merck.

name: Adam de la Zerda
description: Assistant Professor of Structural Biology, Stanford University School of Medicine. Here's a crazy idea: using sound waves to image the body at the molecular level. De la Zerda, who may be the youngest faculty member at the School of Medicine at Stanford University, is making it work, using the technology to take pictures of brain tumors, blood, and living mice. His early efforts led to a startup, OcuBell, focused on eye disease.

name: Nicholas Downing
description: Medical student, Yale University School of Medicine. Nicholas Downing has set his sights on understanding how it is that doctors get information from the Food and Drug Administration and the European Medicines Authority. His first published paper evaluated how drug giant Abbott Labs kept a drug from going generic. A second showed that the FDA, contrary to its critics, is actually faster at approving drugs than other regulators. Several more big studies are forthcoming.

name: Richard Gaster
description: CEO, Gaster Hall Technologies. Gaster was granted his first patent at age 14 and has published 20 peer-reviewed publications. He's also starting a residency in plastic surgery. His first company, Gaster Hall, is developing a small, calculator-sized electronic kit designed to test for cancer and infectious diseases like HIV without a trained technician. A second, wearBIO, is creating wearable electronics for fetal monitoring.

name: Mitchell Guttman
description: Assistant Professor of Biology, California Institute of Technology. Lots of researchers discover genes; Guttman co-discovered a new type of gene. Traditional genes code for proteins, the body's building blocks. The ones Guttman found instead make long-non-coding RNA (lncRNA), which seems to play a key role in organizing which genes work. One lncRNA, for instance, turns off a female mammal's second X chromosome during embryonic development.

name: Daniel Paul Hashim
description: Founder, Carbon Sponge Solutions. Hashim, a Ph.D. candidate at Rice, uses nanotechnology to build futuristic devices. In one case, he used graphene to create what might be a better cathode for ultrafast storage in lithium batteries; in another, carbon nanotubes would be used to heal wounds in people. A carbon nanotube sponge capable of sucking about huge amounts of crude oil has led him to found a company: Carbon Sponge Solutions.

name: Rachel Haurwitz
description: Cofounder, Caribou Biosciences. It's the most promising genetic engineering tool in years: a protein called Cas9, culled from a bacterial system called CRISPR that is used to destroy invading viruses. After seeing the protein's potential while working at a lab at Berkeley, Haurwitz realized it could be used for drug development, crop creation, and industry. She co-founded a company to license Cas9 to companies.

name: Elaine Hsiao
description: Senior Research Fellow, California Institute of Technology. Mind-altering microbes! There are trillions of germs in your body that help regulate your digestion and immune system. Now evidence is building that they might also impact your brain and behavior. One of her most striking findings: a recent paper in which mice with an autism-like disorder were helped when they were fed certain gut bacteria.

name: Cigall Kadoch
description: Assistant Professor of Pediatric Oncology, Dana-Farber Cancer Institute. How genes are read by the cells in our bodies depends in part on their physical structure. Kadoch studies how changes in that physical structure -- caused by mutations in yet other genes – can lead to a particular cancer, synovial sarcoma, a rare soft-tissue malignancy. This work has implications for many cancer types and could eventually lead to new cancer treatments.

name: Aleksandar Kostic
description: Postdoctoral Fellow, Broad Institute of MIT & Harvard. Are germs a root cause of some cancers? This computer scientist's cloud-based methods argue that they are, finding the sequences of a germ, Fusobacterium nucleatum, in many colorectal cancers. Similar work has identified another pathogen, Bradyrhizobium enterica, in colitis, another intestinal disease.

name: Anna F. Lau
description: Clinical Microbiology Fellow, National Institutes of Health. Fungal infections are deadly and hard to treat. Starting as an undergraduate in Australia, Lau has played a role in developing diagnostic tests to detect these microbes, culminating in a new NIH database that may allow doctors to more accurately identify fungi in the blood using mass spectrometry, which determines the chemical content of a sample by ionizing it.

name: Allison Lewko
description: Assistant Professor of Computer Science, Columbia University. If we're going to put all our data in the cloud, how are we going to make sure it's secure? Lewko's research tests existing encryption programs, and then points to ways to improve them. One key question: how to keep secrets on devices, like cloud-connected cell phones, that are frequently leaking information.

name: Joshua Liu
description: Cofounder, Seamless Mobile Health. A novel idea for helping care for patients after surgery: a mobile app that lets a hospital keep in close touch with them to help reduce hospital readmissions. Liu's app won first place at Canada's national eHealth conference. It will be going live in four hospitals across the U.S. and Canada over the next few months.

name: Jonathan Ostrem
description: Consultant, Wellspring Biosciences; Post-doctoral scholar and MD-PhD candidate at UC San Francisco. A protein called ras, which spurs the growth of many cancers, has been beyond the reach of drug hunters because it has a normal form that's needed and potential drugs hit that, too. Ostrem created a drug that blocks only the bad actor. A company, Wellspring Biosciences, has been started to commercialize the work.

name: Michael Pesko
description: Assistant professor, Weill Cornell Medical College. Pesko's work focuses on learning more about the behavior of smokers and how and why they keep lighting up. Three studies documented the many ways smokers avoid higher cigarette prices, foiling attempts to cut their nicotine usage. Another paper showed that one million former smokers took up the habit again due to 9/11 – and then never stopped.

name: Surbhi Sarna
description: Founder, nVision Medical. At age 13, Sarna suffered from ovarian cysts so painful they made her faint. Doctors couldn't tell her if they were cancerous. She vowed to create a technology to detect ovarian cancer quickly and early. The company she now runs aims to do just that, and has raised $4.5 million from Catalyst Health Ventures, Draper Associates, and Astia, a group that assists female entrepreneurs.

name: Josh Sommer
description: Executive Director, Chordoma Foundation. Seven years ago, Josh Sommer found out that he had chordoma, a rare cancer of the skull and spine with a 30% cure rate and no approved drugs. He went to work in the top chordoma lab in the country and created a foundation that has gotten drugmakers interested in the disease.

name: Zirui Song
description: Medical student, Harvard Medical School. Song is doing crucial research on the hottest topic in America: how to reform our healthcare system so it doesn’t waste so much money. One of his New England Journal of Medicine papers showed that the Accountable Care Organizations, a centerpiece of Affordable Care Act, can slow cost growth. A JAMA Internal Medicine paper showed that cutting physician fees didn’t decrease healthcare spending.

name: Marc Succi
description: Cofounder, AugMI Labs. At MIT, he worked in the field of stem cell therapy, but he helped start a company around a glove that can monitor the bloodflow of patients who have undergone vascular surgery; also created 2-Minute Medicine, a medical summarization tool for busy doctors. He is a medical student at Harvard.

name: Livio Valenti
description: Cofounder of Vaxess. One difficulty in getting vaccines to patients in the developing world is keeping them cold –the shots spoil if they're not refrigerated. Valenti's company, Vaxess, uses silk to stabilize vaccines so they can be stored and shipped. The company raised $4.5 million from Norwich Ventures and Angel Investor Jeffrey C. Walker. He is a fellow at Harvard's Center for Business and Government.

name: David Weinberg
description: UCSF Faculty Fellow. As a graduate student, Weinberg described in detail enzymes that products bits of genetic material that shut down other genes – basic science that could improve winemaking or treat human disease and was published in Science and Nature. Now he runs a research lab focused on how cells decide how much of a protein to make, which could lead to insights into cancer.

name: Daniela Witten
description: Assistant Professor of Biostatistics, University of Washington. Witten uses statistical machine learning methods to analyze the large data sets coming out of DNA sequencing and other fields. She is the co-author of a textbook on machine learning, and has published more than 30 articles on new techniques for analyzing these types of data sets - as well as, more recent, a critique of how bad statistics can result in erroneous conclusions.

name: Luhan Yang
description: Cofounder, Egenesis. Yang is trying to engineer personalized organs for drug screening and transplantation. Her company is using genome engineering technology based on Cas9, the genetic engineering tool she studied while getting her Ph.D. at Harvard.

name: Nic Borg
description: Cofounder, Edmodo. In the white-hot world of online educational startups, Nic Borg's Edmodo is among the hottest, raising $25 million in 2012 to total $57 million since it was founded in 2008. Edmodo, a.k.a. "Facebook for the classroom," targets K-12 kids, parents and teachers and has nearly 30 million users—over a million of them teachers—in more than 210,000 schools, including public schools in Chicago and Denver. Edmodo doesn't create "content" but rather is a free, privacy-protected platform where teachers, st

name: Eren Bali
description: Cofounder, Udemy. Bali's brainchild isn't exactly a MOOC, but rather an online learning and teaching bazaar. Instructors are able upload their own courses, set their own prices (or not), and use the platform to attract students of all ages. Over 1.7 million students in 200 countries have signed up since 2010. Originally from Turkey and based in San Francisco, Bali and cofounder Oktay Caglar were rejected 50 times before finding investors, currently at some $16 million.

name: Katie Beck
description: COO, 4.0 Schools. Heads the day-to-day for this early-stage education incubator that brings educators, entrepreneurs, and technologists together. Their alumns have launched 25 new ventures and won prizes such as a Facebook/Gates Foundations HackED 2.0 Award. The Harvard grad’s first job was as a 5th grade English teacher in New Orleans, where she joined Teach For America, most recently working as regional director of strategy and innovation.

name: Catharine Bellinger, Alexis Morin
description: Cofounders, Students for Education Reform. Founded SFER while they were undergraduates at Princeton in 2009. Bellinger and Morin (left) set out to mobilize college students to advocate for K-12 education reform in the voting booth and in state capitols, a mission that has grown to more than 100 chapters on campuses across the country and reaching over a million college students. SFER is scaling so quickly that the founders put their own educations on hold after their junior year and are scheduled to graduate in 2015.

name: Dan Berkowitz
description: Manager, Youth Orchestra LA. Berkowitz took an unorthodox path to maestro Gustavo Dudamel’s signature El Sistema-inspired initiative at the LA Philharmonic. A dual major in music and economics, he's performed trombone with orchestras in Europe, Asia, and the Americas, and also worked with Morningstar UK. Since arriving in 2010, he has grown YOLA from 150 to over 600 students, co-designed four international symposiums on El Sistema and advised emerging programs around the world.

name: Tyler Bosmeny, Dan Carroll, Rafael Garcia
description: Cofounders, Clever. This trio of Harvard classmates (all three have math and/or computer science degrees) cofounded one of the fastest growing ed tech companies in the US. Carroll (center) started with Teach for America in Denver. Later as a school IT director, he realized that there was no standardized software for updating and managing K-12 student data. Clever solves this problem by offering a universal API that connects schools with independent developers who can build apps to manage that information. The compa

name: Andrew Buher
description: COO, NYC Department of Education. In charge of a $25 billion budget serving 1.1 million students, by far the largest of any school system in America. Buher, who has a Master of Public Administration from Columbia University, considers this an achievement as well as a challenge, saying, "The future of education is dependent upon our admitting that the very concept of an all-powerful school system is an outdated model that hinders student learning instead of enhancing it."

name: Sam Chaudhary, Liam Don
description: Cofounders, ClassDojo. Co-CEOs Chaudhary (right) and Don left their native England in 2011 and shared a one-bedroom apartment for months while starting ClassDojo, a software company that helps teachers track classroom behavior. The company says that teachers using the system report 45%-90% increases in positive behavior and 50-85% decreases in negative behavior. Today approximately 18 million teachers and students in 150 countries are users. Chaudhary says Y-Combinator's Paul Graham's essays "inspired us to leave our

name: Sayamindu Dasgupta
description: PhD student, MIT Media Lab. Dasgupta is vital to the Lifelong Kindergarten Research Group’s Scratch project, which enables kids to program their own games, animated stories, and art and share them with millions of other children around the world. Before joining the MIT team, the West Bengal University of Technology grad worked with One Laptop Per Child, where he architected a project that allowed kids to read eBooks in their own languages.

name: Katelyn Donnelly, Saad Rizvi
description: SVPs, Pearson. Over 1.5 million school children enrolled in school as part of their leadership of an international team reforming the Punjab school system. Donnelly (left) leads Pearson's $15 million emerging market venture fund and sits on the board of the Omega School Chain in Ghana, now educating 20,000 children. Rizvi, executive director of efficacy, is an internationally recognized expert on global education, advises on large-scale reform across Asia, Europe, Africa and North America, and is the author of

name: Aaron Feuer, Xan Tanner, David Carel
description: Cofounders, Panorama Education. The Yale grads (from left: Feuer, Tanner, Carel) saw their company become one of the most talked about ed tech startups of the year when it announced $4 million in seeding funding from Mark Zuckerberg's Startup: Education, among others, in October. Panorama is specifically designed for K-12 schools to help them find data-driven solutions by collecting and analyzing feedback from teachers, parents, students and staff. It's now used in more than 4,000 schools serving more than one million students

name: Alejandro Gac-Artigas
description: Founder, Springboard Collaborative. This former 1st grade teacher turned social entrepreneur's goal is to close the literacy gap by transforming the summer from a barrier into a springboard for financially disadvantaged students and families. The Harvard and UPenn grad is a Teach for America and McKinsey & Company alum.

name: Brad Hargreaves, Matt Brimer
description: Cofounders, General Assembly. General Assembly offers classes, workshops, full-time immersive programs and online education on the most relevant skills of the 21st century economy, including web development, user experience design, digital marketing and data science. The goal is to fill today's skills gap by producing tech, business and design talent - and match that talent with GA's professional network. Hargreaves (left) and Brimer orginally cofounded the biz with Adam Pritzker and Jake Schwartz.

name: Jeremy Johnson
description: Cofounder, 2U. 2U is a pioneer in administering and marketing for-credit undergrad and graduate level coursework and degrees with top schools such as Georgetown, Washington, and Northwestern universities and international partners Trinity College Dublin and University of Melbourne. Johnson started the company with Princeton Review founder John Katzman and former Hooked on Phonics CEO Chip Paucek. It has raised $103 million in funding.

name: Jeremiah Kittredge
description: Founder, Families for Excellent Schools. Two key interests define Kittredge's work: Union organizing and public education. FFES helps parents organize for education reform, specifically in charter schools, and currently works with more than 50,000 families in the New York tri-state region. He’s worked as a public school teacher and union organizer in New York, Rhode Island, and New Hampshire, holding positions with Obama for America and SEIU, a 2 million strong union of service workers. A graduate of Brown University, he lives in Brook

name: Jennifer Chen, Joyce Meng
description: Cofounders, Givology. Creating a social enterprise with global impact doesn’t necessarily take a billionaire or a rock star. Chen (right) and Meng's 100% volunteer-run group connects donors to grassroots education projects and student scholarships around the world. They started as students at UPenn in 2008 and have so far raised more than $400,000 for teacher training, school lunch programs, library construction and scholarships in 27 countries. The pair recently coauthored "A Guide To Giving," written collectively b

name: Garrett Neiman
description: Cofounder, CollegeSpring. Started the nonprofit in 2008 while still an economics undergraduate at Stanford University. His mission is to help low-income students achieve higher SAT scores and college acceptances. It is California's largest nonprofit provider in the space, with 5,000 students served and $5 million raised, including backing from Stanford University President John Hennessy, angel investor Ron Conway, and Facebook COO Sheryl Sandberg.

name: Greg Rosenbaum
description: Producer, SXSWedu. Credited with helping to build the education mecca in Austin, Tex., from the ground up. SXSWedu brings together innovators and thought leaders in education -- past guests have included Bill Gates and actor Levar Burton and 2014 speakers include former U.S. Sec. of Education Rod Paige and science wunderkund Jack Andraka. Rosenbaum, a dual major in music and economics at Kenyon College, believes the "future of education is efficient, personalized learning determined by self-driven pathways."

name: Alison Johnston Rue
description: Cofounder, InstaEDU. "The future of education is combining the power of great teachers and great technologies to provide the best possible education for each student," says Rue. That's the emphasis of her two-year-old online tutoring service that matches students 13 and up with experts, mostly in STEM subjects. Under CEO Rue's leadership, InstaEDU has grown 50% month over month in 2013 and raised $5.1 million in funding. Sessions cost students under $45 an hour and the most active and top-rated instructors can pull

name: Elliot Sanchez
description: Founder, mSchool. Sanchez's mSchool has earned a slew of honors, including Teach for America's 2013 Social Innovation Award. The appeal of mSchool is that it is a one room schoolhouse for the 21st century. Its mission is to help community centers open accredited, state-funded classrooms that primarily use adaptive personalization learning software. So far he's opened 14 mSchools in Louisiana, with pilots scheduled in early 2014 in Pennsylvania, New Mexico and Florida, and 20 more pending, including sites in South

name: Kane Sarhan
description: Cofounder, Enstitute. Enstitute is creating the first learn-by-doing university for business, technology, design, and entrepreneurship. Instead of sitting in the classroom, students spend one to two years working as apprentices to founders and CEOs at startups and corporations, supplemented by online and classroom curriculum. The Pace University graduate says his inspiration was his time spent as an apprentice to one of the owners of Coyote Ugly and to the CEO of LocalResponse.

name: Beth Schmidt
description: Founder, Wishbone. Kickstarting education, Wishbone is a scalable web platform that links at-risk high school students with the online donor community to fund their educational dreams. These opportunities to participate in extracurricular activities helps them identify and pursue their passions and career goals.

name: Mandela Schumacher-Hodge
description: Director, Startup Weekend Education. This year the Ph.D. candidate joined UP Global to head the worldwide initiative that helps educators, parents, students, entrepreneurs, developers, and designers who want to create viable companies in the emerging education and learning markets. Schumacher-Hodge is a cofounder of Tioki, an award-winning online professional network exclusively for the education community, dubbed "The LinkedIn for Teachers."

name: Elizabeth Ratner Slavitt
description: Content scaling lead, Khan Academy. Leads a team of educators and researchers for the popular free educational site to create new math content and tools in time for the large-scale adoption of the Common Core Standards. The UPenn graduate started her career at McKinsey and now says she is excited "to push the boundaries on education."

name: Zakiya Smith
description: Strategy director, Lumina Foundation. After leaving the White House as a senior advisor for education, Smith joined the Lumina Foundation in 2013, the largest private foundation in the country focused solely on improving higher education attainment, with over $1 billion in assets. The financial aid shopping sheet she helped design is being used in nearly 2,000 colleges that serve some 8 million undergraduate students.

name: Evan Stone, Sydney Morris
description: Cofounders, Educators 4 Excellence. In 2010, these two former NYC public school teachers and Teach for America alumni founded this teacher-centric voice for public and policy debates in education, including teacher evaluations and the Common Core State Standards. It now has 13,000 members nationally, and is funded in part by the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation and Carnegie Corporation of NY. Says Stone (right), "The future of education is dependent on our ability to elevate the role of the teacher as a leader in our schools, distr

name: Andrew Sutherland
description: Founder, Quizlet. Created by Sutherland when he was 15 to study high school French vocabulary, Quizlet now sees over 20 million unique visitors monthly, from grade to grad school students. Learning comes by way of user-generated tools and games, with over 30 million study sets on the platform on subjects as varied as languages and law to geometry and geography. Quizlet, a top 5 free education app in iTunes App Store, has grown the business with no VC funding.

name: David Tjaden
description: Chair, Student Program, National Education Association. Represents the interests of more than 60,000 future educators on policy issues at federal, state and local levels in all 50 states and on 1,100 college campuses, making the NEA the largest organized association of college students in the country. Tjaden, who started as a research assistant at the University of Iowa Center for Human Rights, lobbies Congressional offices and organizes youth groups around issues pertinent to public education, student loan debt, and college affordability.

name: Caryn Voskuil
description: Manager, school model innovation, Rocketship Education. Voskuil helps lead school model innovation in one of America's fastest growing charter network schools. She began her career as an English teacher in Washington, D.C. public schools, but swiftly became a trainer of teachers. She is charged with managing all digital curriculum and instructional technology that appears on more than 5,000 student screens, including replacing old hardware with over 3,500 Chromebooks.

name: Tony Wan
description: Managing editor, EdSurge News. Over the past two years, Wan has helped shape EdSurge as a go-to source for education technology. With a BA in History from UC San Diego and a master's in East Asian Studies from Stanford University, he covers entrepreneurial companies and has a still-small yet growing following online and on the speaker circuit. Before joining EdSurge, he helped start Luckybird Games, which developed educational math games.

name: Nate Levine
description: Founder, OpenGov. As a Stanford sophomore, Nate Levine saw opportunity where governments have historically been flat-footed. "Governments struggle to access [their own] data, because there aren't good tools out there," Levine says. With that in mind, he cofounded OpenGov in 2012 at age 20. OpenGov's software platform helps governments make intelligent, data-driven decisions and communicate financial information with their constituents. The startup has raised over $7 million—$4 million in 2013 alone—and works with

name: Josh Blackman
description: Assistant professor of law, South Texas College of Law, Houston. Prolific professor and writer covering the Supreme Court, constitutional law and tech policy who’s considered a star in his field already. In September, he published the well-received "Unprecedented: The Constitutional Challenge to Obamacare." Also operates FantasySCOTUS.net, the Internet's premier Supreme Court Fantasy League and prediction market.

name: Amanda Brown
description: National political director, Rock the Vote. Getting young voters to the polls through digital tools and effective civic engagement programming. Previously worked as an Advisor for Strategic Planning at the Department of Energy and an assistant in the White House Office of Political Affairs. Dartmouth grad who deferred law school at the University of Chicago to organize for the Obama campaign.

name: Adam Chandler
description: Attorney, Department of Justice. Rhodes Scholar is the youngest lawyer handling the Federal government’s antitrust appeals. He was the first entry-level attorney hired into the Antitrust Division’s Appellate Section in 18 years. Came out as gay earlier this year in a widely read New York Times op-ed.

name: Leif Dautch
description: Deputy attorney general, California Department of Justice. Yale, Harvard Law grad has argued and won 12 criminal cases representing the state in California Court of Appeals, and has filed briefs in 25 other cases currently pending. Previous stints at white-shoe stalwart Cravath, clerking for Judge Carlos T. Bea on the Ninth Circuit, and the Obama campaign.

name: David Demirbilek
description: Minority counsel, Senate Homeland Security & Governmental Affairs Committee. Legal point man to conservative bulldog Senator Coburn (R-OK) in the Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Committee. He pinpoints waste, fraud and duplication in areas ranging from the federal civil service to the National Park System. Recently steered the Government Accountability Office Improvement Act through the committee favorably, and POTUS is expected to sign it into law.

name: Audrey Gelman
description: Vice president, SKDKnickerbocker. Spokesperson and strategist in Scott Stringer’s come-from-behind victory against former Governor Eliot Spitzer in the fiercely competitive race for New York City Comptroller. Recently promoted to Vice President within six months at SKDKnickerbocker, landing key clients in real estate, tech and apparel. Also made cameos on pal Lena Dunham's HBO hit "Girls" and serves as inspiration for its type-A character Marnie.

name: Jake Heller
description: Cofounder, Casetext. Making the world's laws free and understandable, using a Wikipedia-like approach to crowdsource the work for this endeavor. Has raised over $1.5 million from investors including Y Combinator, SV Angel, CrossLink Capital and Ashton Kutcher. Casetext is already used by over 100,000 lawyers to do research every month. Left Ropes & Gray to pursue Casetext. Former Stanford Law Review President.

name: Solomon Hsiang
description: Assistant professor of public policy, University of California, Berkeley. Lead author on the first study to show that global climate is likely to have causal effect on global rates of civil conflict. Researches climatic impact on societies using statistics, particularly how environmental change affects the ways that economies function. Developing novel ways to 'price' global climate’s value. Lead author of research papers in Nature, Science and PNAS.

name: Tim Hwang
description: Partner, Robot, Robot & Hwang. Researching disruptive tech and automation in the legal marketplace as the sole human partner at the offices of Robot, Robot & Hwang. Investigating regulatory framework around intelligent systems with Microsoft’s danah boyd at the Data and Society Research Institute. Developing tabletop games to teach real-world policy scenarios, including a pen-and-pencil RPG on Too Big To Fail. Stanford Center for Legal Informatics Fellow.

name: Cristina Jimenez
description: Managing director, United We Dream. Organizes immigrant youth to advance their rights and those of their families regardless of immigration status. Came to the U.S. with her family at the age of 13 from Ecuador, attending high school and college as an undocumented student.

name: Noorain Khan
description: Associate, Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz. Rhodes Scholar specializes in M&A, corporate governance, debt offerings and funds practice at one of the most celebrated—and exclusive—firms in the country. A Soros Fellow at Yale Law School, she’s traveled abroad with the State Department to speak about Islam in the U.S. Former stints at Goldman Sachs, Google and Department of Justice.

name: Derek Khanna
description: Tech policy scholar, Activist. Copyright reform report for the House Republican Study Committee was championed by conservatives, progressives and tech experts but pressure from special interest groups forced it offline. Then he launched the cellphone unlocking campaign that included the first White House petition to reach 100,000 signatures, resulting in introduced legislation. Participated in StopWatching.Us coalition, leading to introduction of USA Freedom Act.

name: Eric King
description: Head of research, Privacy International. Rebuilt Privacy International. Launched Big Brother Inc., a campaign to limit the export of surveillance technologies to repressive regimes. Collected and released companies’ brochures and information about their practices. Committed to defending the right to privacy and launched litigation around the world to ensure that surveillance is consistent with the rule of law.

name: Aaron Letzeiser
description: Founder, Medical Amnesty Initiative. Founder of the only nonprofit in the U.S. specifically dedicated to the introduction, passage and education of Medical Amnesty legislation nationwide. After successfully drafting and pushing medical amnesty through in Michigan, similar legislation has now been passed in 17 states, and Washington, D.C, with a goal of 40 states by the end of 2014.

name: Yihong "Julie" Mao
description: Attorney, New Orleans Workers' Center for Racial Justice. NYU Law grad provides legal and strategic support to NOWCRJ’s immigrant and guestworker memberships, including direct representation of guestworker-victims of labor trafficking, civil rights litigation and advocating for reforms to protect immigrant victims. Involved in the largest government enforcement action against employers and recruiters for exploiting J-1 student guestworkers that led to new State Department oversight and program regulations.

name: Blake Masters
description: Cofounder, Judicata. Big believer in law with a Valley ethos, building advanced legal research, analytics and AI tools for lawyers with the goal of creating the world’s highest quality legal dataset. Judicata is backed by Khosla Ventures, SV Angel, Peter Thiel and Aaron Levie. Co-authored the forthcoming "Zero To One" with Thiel, after his notes from Thiel's startups class went viral.

name: Jonathan Mayer
description: Cybersecurity fellow, Center for International Security and Cooperation. Contributed to FTC investigation into Google for circumventing Apple privacy settings, resulting in a $22.5 million fine for the search giant, one of the largest FTC fines ever. Worked with Mozilla on a new Firefox cookie policy. Measuring the privacy impact of NSA phone and Internet surveillance. Arrived at Stanford to pursue its first ever JD/PhD in Computer Science.

name: Teryn Norris
description: Commercialization & manufacturing specialist, U.S. Department of Energy. Cofounded a major new Department of Energy initiative to strengthen U.S. competitiveness in clean energy manufacturing. Led development of a multi-million dollar DOE program to support business incubators for clean energy startups nationwide. Co-led projects to reform tech transfer at the National Labs and create a new philanthropic asset class for energy innovation. Cofounded the Millennial Action Project.

name: Corey Owens
description: Head of public policy, Uber. Preaching the gospel of smarter, more efficient transportation systems to anybody who will listen. His efforts for Uber have paid off in Columbus, Charlotte, Jacksonville, Dallas, Denver and Seattle. Since March, his team has grown from one to nine employees as more standoffs with wary municipalities loom.

name: Jonathan Fantini Porter
description: Chief of staff for management, U.S. Department of Homeland Security, U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement. Oversees day-to-day management operations of a $5.8 billion Federal budget for 20,000 employees in 48 countries at DHS. Formerly the youngest to lead a legislative office in the House of Representatives. Father was a political prisoner in Argentina's Dirty War, while mother handled his case as a human rights activist, successfully leading U.S. State Department to push for his eventual release.

name: Jessica Schumer
description: Chief of staff, Council of Economic Advisers, Executive Office of the President. Helping bring the CEA into the 21st century, serving as Chairman Jason Furman’s principal advisor and CEA’s liaison with other White House offices and federal agencies. Handles legislative affairs and communications at CEA. Leads production of the Economic Report of the President. Responsible for President’s daily economic briefing. Previously at NEC as Senior Policy Advisor and Deputy Chief of Staff.

name: Amie Stepanovich
description: Director, domestic surveillance project, Electronic Privacy Information Center. Expert on drone surveillance, cybersecurity and national security who has testified before Congress on the need for privacy protections for domestic drone use. A New York Law School grad, her work on the privacy implications of surveillance is at the forefront of the current debate on civil liberties in a post-Snowden world.

name: Nabiha Syed
description: Attorney, Levine Sullivan Koch & Schulz. Considered one of the best emerging free speech lawyers. Part of the team representing The Guardian U.S. in its ongoing national security reporting. On the team that defended Eliot Spitzer when Hank Greenberg sued for defamation. Formerly First Amendment Fellow in the New York Times Company’s legal department. Cofounded Drone U, an educational platform explaining drone integration into civilian airspace.

name: Trevor Timm
description: Executive director, Freedom of the Press Foundation. Activist with EFF ubiquitous in battle against NSA spying and Obama administration's war on whistleblowers. Cofounded Freedom of the Press Foundation which supports and defends journalism organizations who report on secrecy and national security. Glenn Greenwald, Laura Poitras and Dan Ellsberg sit on its board. New York Law School grad won Hugh Hefner First Amendment Award for journalism this year. Co-operates popular @drones Twitter account.

name: Rebecca Vallas
description: Deputy director of government affairs, National Organization of Social Security Claimants' Representatives. Advocates for strengthened economic security for seniors and people with disabilities, on the Hill and through the media. Order of the Coif UVA Law grad, former Skadden Fellow and youngest member of the National Academy on Social Insurance—the nation's leading experts on social insurance. Inaugural recipient of National Legal Aid and Defender Association's New Leaders in Advocacy award.

name: Heather West
description: Policy analyst, Google. Works on security and privacy issues at the place where they matter most. A policy-to-tech translator, product consultant and long-term Internet strategist, she works with stakeholders and policymakers as well as Google’s global product and policy teams on mobile, Do Not Track and identity policy. Currently advising on global privacy and security issues, from NSA revelations to location privacy.

name: Cody R. Wilson
description: Founder, Defense Distributed. Texan crypto-anarchist is the man behind the world’s first fully 3D-printed gun, the Liberator. He sees the gun as a symbolic step toward a private law society, where power rests with people rather than intrusive government. Now at work on a Bitcoin wallet, and has gone to bat for fellow crypto-anarchist, Ross Ulbricht, the alleged mastermind behind Silk Road.

name: Lauren Wilson
description: Policy counsel, Free Press. Fights major broadcast mergers, which have been using shared service agreements to evade the FCC's ban on duopolies, and which hurt the journalism industry and ownership by women and people of color. Big win came when FCC approved an order slashing prison phone rates, helping low income communities. Shining a light on the anticompetitive harms wireless spectrum consolidation would cause.

name: Daniel Zolnikov
description: State representative, Montana House District 47. Pushing privacy bills in his home state that shield Americans in lieu of federal action against NSA disclosures. Backed and passed law before Snowden’s leaks that requires a search warrant to obtain cell phone location information. Now focusing on protecting journalistic sources, requiring consent to obtain personal information and preventing or limiting states’ use of license plate scanning technology.

name: Trip Adler
description: Cofounder, Scribd. An avid surfer and sometime street-busking saxophonist with a Harvard degree in biophysics, Adler is a man of many interests. He thinks readers ought to be able to indulge their own diverse curiosities as well—and be able to "think about what to read, not what to buy," as he says. Scribd, the digital content-sharing platform he cofounded in 2007, is betting big on subscriptions: $8.99 a month for unlimited e-book downloads. It has already partnered with more than 100 publishers for a catalog of

name: Pete Cashmore
description: Founder, Mashable. Cashmore founded Mashable in his parents' home near Aberdeen, Scotland. What started as a one-man blog has since grown into a global technology news operation with more than 20 million unique monthly visitors. By bootstrapping the operation, Cashmore reportedly has maintained near-total ownership.

name: Kelly Evans
description: Anchor, CNBC. One of the most recognizable young faces on CNBC, Evans co-hosts the daily show "Squawk on the Street." She earned her stripes in business news at the Wall Street Journal, where she was a cross-platform whiz, writing the "Ahead of the Tape" and "Heard on the Street" columns and hosting "News Hub," a daily video segment.

name: Dan Fletcher
description: Cofounder, Beacon. Fletcher started a publishing platform that helps journalists get paid by readers directly for their work. Previously managing editor of Facebook; also held social media/journalism positions at Bloomberg News and Time, where he helped those legacy organizations navigate the migration to digital.

name: Matt Galligan
description: Cofounder, Circa. Circa, which delivers news to readers in a format optimized for mobile consumption, is Galligan's third start-up. His first, Socialthing, aggregated updates across social networks; AOL bought it in 2008. His next was a geo-location service provider called SimpleGeo; UrbanAirship acquired it in 2011.

name: Tavi Gevinson
description: Cofounder, Rookie. Gevinson has yet to reach voting age but has already undergone several career evolutions. Originally a style blogger, she's broadened her focus to feminism and other topics with Rookie, her two-year-old website. She's also been landing acting roles.

name: Axel Hansen, Jonah Varon
description: Cofounders, Newsle. Hansen (right) and Varon were studying computer science together at Harvard when they cooked up the idea for a news service that keeps you up to date on the doings of people in your social networks. They went on leave to pursue it full time, backed by more than $2.5 million from the likes of Advance Publications, Lerer Ventures, SV Angel and Transmedia Capital.

name: Jake Horowitz, Chris Altchek
description: Cofounders, PolicyMic. Friends since they were high school classmates at NYC's Horace Mann, Horowitz (right) and Altchek cofounded PolicyMic, a fast-growing news site and conversation platform aimed at millennials who care about real issues. Backers include Knight Enterprise Fund; total funding raised is $5 million so far.

name: David Karp
description: Founder, Tumblr. While his peers were attending high school, boy-genius Karp was working full time as a website designer and programmer. By age 19 he'd started Tumblr, the social blogging platform that he would end up selling to Yahoo for $1.1 billion in 2013. An $81 million bonus package will likely keep him at the company for the next three years.

name: Ezra Klein
description: Columnist, Washington Post. Klein is one of the best-known and most widely read columnists at the Washington Post and has been since he joined the paper in 2009. He's been blogging about politics since 2003, and is also a frequent on-air presence on MSNBC. The left-leaning Klein is also a columnist for Bloomberg View.

name: Dan Koh
description: General manager, HuffPost Live. As Arianna Huffington's chief of staff, Koh helped keep a 700-person news organization with seven international editions running smoothly. Now he does the same at HuffPost Live, the ambitious interactive internet TV venture launched in 2012. Before joining HuffPost, he served as an advisor to Boston mayor Thomas Menino.

name: Chris Lavergne, Alex Magnin
description: Founder, COO, Thought Catalog. Founded in 2010 by CEO Lavergne (right), a former Wall Street consultant, Thought Catalog thinks of itself as an experimental media collective. Millennial earnestness is the dominant tone of the essays it publishes, which can be confessional, political or just silly. All viewpoints are welcomed; no observation is too jejune. Magnin is the architect of Thought Catalog's ad sales strategy.

name: Libby Leffler
description: Strategic partnerships manager, Facebook. Leffler is the point person on Facebook's partnerships with media organizations, nonprofits, world leaders, executives and other important entities. Her past roles at the company include service as co-anchor of the streaming video presentation "Facebook Live" and assisting Sheryl Sandberg as her business lead, managing the "Lean In" author's public appearances and other projects. Like Sandberg, she's a Google veteran.

name: Uzoamaka Maduka
description: Cofounder, The American Reader. Maduka is a mix of modern and throwback: A child of Nigerian immigrants and Princeton graduate, she decided to start a literary magazine, in print, at a time when most of her classmates were dreaming of launching hit apps. There's a daily website, too, and a partnership with Salon.com helps with digital distribution.

name: Claire Mazur
description: Cofounder, Of A Kind. Mazur and her cofounder, Erica Cerulo, were early to the trend of integrating content and commerce around fashion. Of A Kind, which they started in 2010, helps emerging designers sell their wares by bringing the stories behind them to life. Despite never having raised venture capital, the site is already generating seven-figure sales.

name: Brit Morin
description: Founder, Brit + Co. The closest thing Silicon Valley has to a Martha Stewart, Morin uses YouTube videos and other digital media channels to inspire people to take up arts and crafts. The "Brit Kits" she sells take some of the "Y" out of "DIY." A veteran of Apple and Google, she's married to Path founder Dave Morin.

name: Matt Mullenweg
description: Founder, Automattic. In a classic entrepreneurship story, Mullenweg created Wordpress to satisfy his own need for a better blogging tool. A true believer in the open-source philosophy, he has largely resisted pressure to commercialize his creation, which powers one in six blogs. An enterprise version provides the revenues that keep his company running and his investors happy.

name: Carolyn Penner
description: Head of product communications, Twitter. As Twitter's chief spokesperson on the product side during the run-up to its massive IPO, Penner has been holding down what's arguably one of the most high-profile communications jobs in American business. She thrives under the microscope, having previously handled public affairs at Google.

name: Tiffany Pham
description: Director of business development, strategic initiatives and partnerships, CBS. Pham has a long title and an even longer resume: A Harvard Business School grad, she handles partnerships and strategic initiaitives for more than 150 digital assets at CBS while also producing documentaries and feature films and acting as head of marketing for the Beijng International Screenwriting Competition. She also wrote a book about business strategy and information technology.

name: Olenka Polak
description: Cofounder, MyLingo. Olenka's upbringing in a Polish-speaking household gave her the idea for a service that would allow viewers to watch movies and TV shows in English while hearing real-time translations. Her concept won the 2013 Harvard Innovation Challenge and attracted attention from investors. Polak dropped out of Harvard to pursue MyLingo full time.

name: Sterling Proffer
description: Director of platform, Vice. Proffer is the man in charge of fast-growing Vice Media's digital distribution and strategy. A Vice employee right out of college, he helped the company win funding from Google to launch its YouTube channels, which have millions of subscribers and have produced half a billion views. He also launched Vice's technology vertical, Motherboard.

name: Rachel Rosenfelt
description: Cofounder, The New Inquiry. As a freshman at Barnard, Rosenfelt secured a coveted internship at The New Yorker. But instead of grasp the bottom rung of the ladder, she and two friends created The New Inquiry, an outlet for young writers who, like her, find their creative aspirations frustrated by the dwindling of old media.The New Inquiry is digital-only, supported by subscriptions and live events.

name: Melissa Rosenthal
description: Director of creative services, Buzzfeed. Native advertising is the focus of Buzzfeed's revenue strategy, and perhaps the most important trend in the media business. Rosenthal oversees a 40-person team that produces native ads that readers read and share just like articles -- in theory, at least. Rosenthal established BuzzFeed's creative department and is now helping recreate it in other countries.

name: Callie Schweitzer
description: Director of digital innovation, Time. Building an "innovation hub" at the Time Inc. newsweekly, Schweitzer serves as the pivot point between editorial, business and marketing. A champion networker online and off, she was previously head of marketing at Vox Media and deputy publisher at Talking Points Memo. She has the media business in her blood: Her father is George Schweitzer, longtime head of marketing for CBS.

name: Nikhil Sethi, Garrett Ullom
description: Cofounders, Adaptly. Sethi (right) and Ullom have been friends since they met in a classroom at Northwestern University. (The course: Probability of Statistics in Random Signals.) Adaptly is their solution for advertisers who are overwhelmed by the challenges of managing their campaigns across numerous social platforms. They developed the idea in an incubator program sponsored by DreamIt Ventures.

name: Shane Snow
description: Cofounder, Contently. Former journalist who cofounded (along with two friends) a company to take advantage of rise of branded content. Launched out of TechStars NY, Contently now has a network of more than 25,000 freelancers. It has 24 full time employees and has raised $3 million in funding.

name: Jason Stein
description: Founder, Laundry Service. Stein's Laundry Service sits at the intersection of social media marketing and branded content. Just two years in, it already has more than 30 employees in New York and Los Angeles. Fun fact: Stein solicited his first client with a Craigslist ad. Amazon, Disney and the Jones Group have since followed.

name: Brian Stelter
description: Host, Reliable Sources, CNN. After covering the TV news business since he was in college, Stelter is now a part of it, having won a bake-off to become the new host of "Reliable Sources," CNN's weekly press criticism show. His blog TV Newser led to a job at The New York Times, from which perch he published "Top of the Morning," a bestselling nonfiction book about the morning TV wars.

name: Eric Stromberg
description: Cofounder, Oyster. Whether you liken it to Netflix or Spotify, Oyster is trying to introduce to the book business the same all-you-can-eat consumption that's proven popular in other parts of the digital media world. Peter Thiel's Founders Fund led its most recent venture round. Stromberg worked in business development at Hunch, leaving shortly after it was acquired by eBay.

name: Fernando Vila
description: VP of programming, Fusion. A Miami native, Vila is helping Disney's ABC build its way into the U.S. Hispanic market with Fusion, the English-language news network it launched in 2013 in partnership with Univision. Before joining Univision in 2011, he cofounded the Americas Business Council Foundation.

name: Brian Wong
description: Cofounder, Kiip. Imagine you just posted a 5-mile run to the RunKeeper app when an ad on your iPhone pops up offering you a free liter of Propel Water. Or you just finished a particularly fiendish level of Candy Crush and you are offered free Sour Patch Kids as a reward. These "moments of achievement" and "serendipitous rewards" are a big part of the future of advertising, at least according to Wong, who cofounded Kiip in 2010, a year after graduating from the University of British Columbia at age 17. "We track

name: Katrina Bekessy
description: Director of technology & design, R/GA. Part technologist, part designer, Bekessy is a Parsons grad and interaction-design specialist at R/GA, a digital agency, handling technical strategy and implementation across channels--websites, social, mobile, and enterprise-level systems. She has worked on projects for clients such as Walmart and McCormick, and leads the technology department in R/GA’s Austin/Southwest region.

name: Mallory Blair
description: Cofounder, Small Girls PR. Cofounded a PR firm that prioritizes personable media relations. Since starting three years ago, the firm has become the agency of record for technology companies such as GE and Meetup as well as the promotional arm for media companies like Flavorpill and Gawker. It has never used a wire, rarely writes press releases, and never sends blanket pitches, relying instead on creative partnerships with bloggers and founders.

name: Derek Blais
description: Senior art director, BBDO Canada. In his nine years of experience, Blais has created digital, social and branded-content campaigns for brands such as Heineken and PepsiCo. His work has garnered awards from the Cannes Lions International Festival of Creativity, Effies, The One Show and Webby Awards, among others. A McDonald's campaign, "Our Food. Your Questions," recently won nine Golds and Best In Show at the Canadian Marketing Association Awards. He has been shortlisted as a "Marketer on The Rise" nominee by the American Market

name: Raymond Braun
description: LGBT marketing lead, Google/YouTube. Also associate product marketing manager, YouTube Entertainment Marketing, Braun originated and led YouTube’s first-ever marketing campaign, #ProudToLove, dedicated to celebrating the LGBT community, which involved turning the YouTube logo rainbow. The campaign has won marketing awards and been widely praised by LGBT thought leaders and influencers. Leads global LGBT marketing initiatives and community outreach for YouTube/Google.

name: Victor Cheng, Roger Lee
description: Cofounders, PaperG. Cofounded PaperG, a company whose technology can automatically create and distribute display ads across platforms and devices -- lowering the cost of online advertising for small- and medium-sized businesses. PaperG has been named one of Forbes’ 100 Most Promising Companies in America. Clients include Hearst, Time Warner Cable, Charter Communications, and Tribune.

name: Katrina Craigwell
description: Global manager of digital marketing, GE. Leads content for the digital marketing team at General Electric. Drives content creation and distribution across GE.com, Txchnologist.com and GE's corporate properties internationally, as well as GE's social-media presences on platforms including Instagram, Tumblr and YouTube. Has spent the last two-and-a-half years at GE bringing the company's technology to life via visual content. In November 2013, she began a two-month assignment in Dubai, working with the GE MENAT team on digital brand stra

name: David Dinetz, Dylan Trussell, Colt Seman
description: Cofounders, Culprit Creative. Cofounded an agency that specializes in brand storytelling. Clients include King, makers of the Candy Crush app, and Legendary Pictures, the makers of the Dark Knight Trilogy and Inception. The agency is currently pitching Tesla. Dinetz was previously director of production at Ignition Creative, where he helped spearhead the Tomb Raider video game campaign. Trussell has been Dinetz's creative partner since college; he directed commercials for brands such as ESPN and Mattel. Seman is a cinematogr

name: Andrew Dumont
description: Director of business development, Moz. At Moz, a marketing analytics platform with more than 25,000 clients such as Disney, FedEx, Starbucks and Boeing, Dumont is responsible for business development, overseeing a team responsible for growth initiatives such as data licensing, product distribution and strategic partnerships. He created the company’s product distribution channel; it now accounts for more than 4% of total revenue, which was $27 million in 2013. Previously he was a cocreator at Stride and director of business developmen

name: Whitney Fishman
description: Tech and consumer insights director, MEC. Since joining MEC in 2013, Fishman has developed new client communication tools, helped launch the agency’s innovation initiative and revamped the agency’s thought leadership program. She oversees the creation of proprietary educational materials for clients. She previously held positions at MediaVest, Grey and Buzz Marketing Group. Fishman also cofounded Summer Air Records in 2004, an independent music label specializing in artist relations, public relations and marketing, and is a founding boa

name: Teddy Goff
description: Cofounder, Precision Strategies. Former digital director for Obama For America, where he oversaw a team of more than 200 people nationwide managing the campaign's social media, email, web, online advertising, online organizing, design, front-end and product development, design, and video strategies. At Precision Strategies, he is applying expertise in digital, communications, and data and analytics to the private sector. Clients include The Mark Cuban Cos., Microsoft and the Democratic National Committee.

name: Rich Greco
description: Head of design, Droga5. Greco heads design at this creative and strategic agency, overseeing a staff of eight designers. He has been working professionally since 2007 and previously worked at MTV, Lowe New York and Deutsch Inc. Droga5 clients include Prudential, American Express, The Coca-Cola Co., Motorola, Under Armour, Mondelez International, Chobani, Spotify and UNICEF. He was cited as one of Business Insider’s 30 Most Creative People in Advertising Under 30.

name: Jack Hanlon
description: Cofounder, Kinetic Social. Also head of product, Hanlon is the architect of the data-focused Kinetic Social tech platform, which helps marketers and their agencies manage campaigns across social platforms and also gain an understanding of their audiences. The company's more than 500 clients since launch include Mars, H&M and Victoria's Secret's PINK. In one quarter he increased profitability from 19% to 53% while growing the client portfolio.

name: Amy Karr
description: Experience designer, Starcom MediaVest Group. In her role at media agency Starcom MediaVest Group, Karr was a part of the Experience Design team, a group that has now become Zero Dot, a brand experience consulting group that launched in 2013, of which Karr was cofounder and first employee. Karr devises unique, innovative media ideas and strategies that are inherently designed for the digital age, across multiple screens—highly social and participatory.

name: Joanna Kennedy
description: Senior social media specialist, RPA. Kennedy has helped shape notable, in some cases award-winning, social campaigns for RPA clients including Honda and Intuit--such as the teaser for Honda’s “Matthew’s Day Off” Super Bowl ad. She also drove the seeding strategy for the award-winning (and Cannes Lions International Festival of Creatity-shortlisted) video to promote the Newport Beach Film Festival. Works closely with the agency’s creative, technology and media teams.

name: Greg Kimball
description: Manager of digital strategy and communications, L'Oréal. Tasked with overhauling the digital and social properties of L'Oreal USA, Kimball currently is working on relaunching the corporate website and implementing the corporate team's first social strategy over the next year. He is the winner of a Young Guns Award at L'Oreal.

name: Jack Krawczyk
description: Director of product management, Pandora. Krawczyk leads the product-technology team, covering all advertising products at Pandora that are responsible for more than 80% of company revenue. He was previously head of monetization and publisher products at StumbleUpon; there he launched Paid Discovery, a platform enabling brands to maximize the reach of their produced content. Before that, he was product marketing manager at Google, where he was on the founding team that developed Google+. He has written extensively on native advertising,

name: Michael Kuzmich
description: Associate director of motion graphics, Firstborn. Kuzmich works at Firstborn, a digital advertising agency with clients such as PepsiCo, L’Oreal, Google and Sony that has produced award-winning work. He specializes in motion graphics, 2D and 3D animation, 3D Studio Max, Autodesk Maya, Photoshop, After Effects, video post-production and  Flash animation. Previously he was an interactive designer and animator at BEAM Interactive.

name: Douglas Lusted
description: Cofounder, WestonExpressions. Lusted founded WestonExpressions, a technology corporation providing hardware and software innovations for the out-of-home advertisement industry, after winning the University of Waterloo’s Innovation Showcase and VeloCity Venture Fund in his second year of business and environment studies. That lead to the development of Linkett technology. Linkett is a small device that enables digital screens to collect data about passing consumers and optimize the digital content toward their demographic.

name: Jeff MacDonald
description: Creative technologist, The Martin Agency. A creative technologist at The Martin Agency, during the school year MacDonald is an adjunct professor at the VCU Brandcenter, as well as the marketing adviser for Feast RVA. During his first year at grad school he co-led creative-technologist classmates in building a website for organizing panel discussions at the 2011 SXSW interactive festival; the site became Panelizr and went from concept to beta in 10 days.

name: Charles Merritt
description: Partner, 80amps. Partner at 80amps, a company that assists startups by providing a combination of seed capital and professional services in exchange for a stake in the company. He has implemented marketing strategies at Kayak.com and Jetsetter.com that fueled growth at each firm. He has also served as a video producer, managing video journalists for an online media startup.

name: Mitch Orkis
description: Director of client development, Vizeum US. At Vizeum, a media agency that is part of Dentsu Aegis and launched in the U.S. in 2011, his role has been to help spur new business growth, which has increased approximately 30% in 18 months. Clients include Pernod Ricard, Seventh Generation, Sonos, and Dow Jones. Awards include 20th Century Fox, Prometheus: Winner of Gold for Media Innovation and Silver for Media Creativity at the Media Week Awards 2012.

name: Khoa Phan
description: Freelance Vine animator. Tapped by notable brands such as Peanuts Worldwide, Snapple, Swiffer, MTV, (RED) and Livestrong to create extremely fluid, storytelling stop-motion videos on Vine. His work has been covered by CNN and Bloomberg TV. Shortlist finalist at Tribeca Film Fest 2013 and Mashable’s Most Creative Stop-Motion Animator.

name: Matthew Rubinger
description: Director of luxury accessories, Heritage Auctions. Rubinger was hired three years ago at a six-figure salary to launch the luxury accessories division of Heritage Auctions — the third largest auctioneer of collectibles in the world and the largest based in the United States. When Rubinger came on board straight out of college, he had never run an auction before. He’s now in charge of three sales a year that together brought in $9 million last year.

name: Maude Standish
description: Cofounder, Tarot. Cofounded a company called Tarot, a Millennial trend insight company and sister company to Mistress Creative, an agency based in Venice, CA. Is also the directory of strategy at Mistress Social, the social division of Mistress Creative that translates the latest trends into social campaigns. Standish is the former executive director at Trendera and writes for Vice, The Huffington Post and Agency Spy. She will be speaking at SXSW this year about the impact the economy of sharing is having on our

name: Rachel Tipograph
description: Global director of digital and social media, Gap. A former strategist at Undercurrent, a digital strategy firm, working with marketers such as PepsiCo, Levi’s and Disney. She also is an angel investor and adviser to early-stage ad-tech and consumer-goods start-ups. Previously, she was a “reverse mentor” at Time Warner, teaching senior executives about social media. She's been a speaker at SXSW, Internet Week and The Corporate Social Media Summit. Under her guidance Gap purchased all mobile ads on Tumblr for a 24-hour time period as part of a pr

name: Elliott Wiener
description: Director of consumer insights, Razorfish. Wiener has experience in A/B and multivariate testing, statistical modeling such as regression analysis and factor analysis, cookie-level media and site-side analysis, survey analysis, media-mix modeling, match-market testing, mobile, and social ROI analysis. In addition, he is certified in Google Analytics, Adobe Analytics products, Unica, Webtrends, Coremetrics, Flurry Mobile Analytics, Atlas, Dart DFA, SQL, SPSS, SAS, and other specialty and web analytics software. Prior to joining Razorfish,

name: Farryn Weiner
description: Global director of digital and social communications, Michael Kors Worldwide. Weiner heads global social strategy for fashion brand Michael Kors Worldwide, overseeing social, editorial and digital marketing and media strategy. She led the development of the first Instagram ad ever, which ran in November. Weiner previously headed up social media, editorial content and marketing strategy for Jetsetter.com at Gilt Groupe. She's been a panelist at SXSW, Internet Week, Social Media Week and Luxury Daily Conference, among others. Accolades include Top 10 Most Stylish Social Med

name: Elyse Winer
description: Marketing and communications manager, MC10 Inc. In just over a year, Winer developed a new, stronger brand identity for MC10, a venture-backed wearable electronics startup. Her work as brand ambassador and product-marketing head led to the successful launch last year of MC10’s first commercial product, the Reebok Checklight, which monitors physical data and gauges head impact of on-field athletes. She has appeared on Fox and Friends and has been quoted in the Boston Globe, among other media outlets, discussing the product and increasing the p

name: Pranav Yadav
description: CEO, Neuro-Insight. After winning the Starr Scholarship (full ride, given to six kids from Asia) to go to Carleton College, India-born Yadav graduated magna cum laude with three majors, then went to Goldman Sachs, where he worked as a sales trader for structured equity derivatives. Left to work for ReD Associates, an innovation strategy consulting firm. He was later introduced to Dr. Richard Silberstein, inventor of Neuro-Insight’s technology, who offered him the position of CEO. Neuro-Insight is a neuromarketing f

name: Carter Cleveland
description: Founder and CEO, Artsy. When Carter Cleveland was a Princeton computer science student back in 2008, he went online searching for a picture to decorate his dorm room. "I assumed there would be a website with all the world's art on it," he recalls. There wasn't. So he set out to build one, with a Pandora-like feature that recommends artists to users. His company, Artsy, displays more than 85,000 pieces of art from 400 foundations and museums (including the National Gallery of Art and the Getty) and 1,400 galleries. Thou

name: Ahmed Abdelrahman
description: Fashion designer, Thamanyah. Born in the United Arab Emirates, Abdelrahman designs androgynous clothes under the name Thamanyah, which means "eight" in Arabic, inspired by his eight siblings and the eight-pointed star that symbolizes the eight gates of heaven used in Islamic art and architecture. His signature creation is a kandora, a traditional, ankle-length Middle-Eastern men's garment. He also designs funnel-necked coats, shirts with a dervish collar, loose-fitting, sculptural jackets.

name: Jensen Adoni
description: Shoemaker, Modern Vice. Founders of Modern Vice shoewear, Jensen and his brother, Jordan, make shoes in midtown Manhattan for national and international retailers. They started their business after their father, a former cobbler, left the trade. The shoes reflect a downtown edge and are often the product of designer collaborations; they're sold in Lord & Taylor, Urban Outfitters, and Macy's, among others.

name: Rosie Assoulin
description: Fashion designer. Assoulin uses rich Italian fabrics to make contemporary twists on American classics. Her debut collection for 2014 includes pantsuits in neutrals like beige, white and black; she accents one black outfit with an oversized gold sash and mixes basics like fitted jackets and drawstring pants with draped asymmetrical dresses.

name: Michelle Campbell
description: Jewelry designer. Launched in 2011, Campbell's collection is sold around the world and has been featured in Vogue, Bazaar, Elle and The New York Times. The looks pull from both natural and manmade surroundings, architecture and an urban city grid. It has a downtown gotham look and feel.

name: Ian Collings
description: Industrial designer, Fort Standard. Together with Gregory Buntain, 30, Collings founded industrial design firm which crafts everything from lighting and furniture like tables, stools and bookcases, to bowls, candelabras and coat hooks. Its products, made of materials like ceramic, wood and bronze, have clean, simple lines. Clients include Warby Parker and All-Clad.

name: Asher Dunn
description: Furniture designer, Studio Dunn. When he was 18 months old Dunn used his Sesame Street screwdriver set to dismantle the ventilation system in his childhood home. Since then he has been fascinated with putting things together. His Studio Dunn in Providence, RI, produces sleek, simple furniture, lighting, bowls and vases that recall mid-20th century modernism. He also founded Keeseh Woodshop, a community workshop that teaches woodworking, and Anchor Providence, an arts and business incubator.

name: Alan Eckstein
description: Design director, Timo Weiland. The men's and women's line features sportswear mixed with sharp but casual suits and feminine, romantic pieces. Founded in 2009 along with creative director Timo Weiland (30), the label was nominated for the Ecco Domani award for women's and men's collections, with the duo later selected to sit on the Council of Fashion Designers of America's Fashion Incubator program. Clothing stocked by Barneys, Pas De Deux, Los Angeles's Satine, and top retailers in Japan.

name: Crystal Ellis, Stephanie Beamer
description: Furniture designers, Egg Collective. Ellis and Beamer are part of a design trio that includes Hillary Petrie, 30. They met as freshmen at Washington University in St. Louis and in 2011, founded furniture design studio Egg Collective, which makes tables, chairs, cabinets, lighting out of organic materials like wood, glass, brass and a mineral called travertine. Their pieces have clean, functional lines with a contemporary edge.Their latest commission: a seating area for New York City Ballet-goers at Lincoln Center.

name: Sarah Flint
description: Shoe designer. Inspired by origami and by classic shoe silhouettes of the 1940s, Flint's shoes are made in Italy and worn by Heidi Klum. She introduced her first collection in the fall of 2013 and has already been featured in The New York Times, Elle, Women's Wear Daily.

name: Alex Gartenfeld
description: Interim director, MOCA North Miami. Has served as online editor of Art in America and Interview magazines. Curated a summer show for OHWOW gallery in L.A. as well as an exhibition that took over Team Gallery's two locations in SoHo last winter. Recently named Interim Director of MOCA North Miami.

name: Wes Gordon
description: Fashion designer. A native of Atlanta, Gordon studied art and design in London and interned with Oscar de la Renta and Tom Ford. Michelle Obama, Gwyneth Paltrow, Kerry Washington and Emily Blunt wear his designs, which include gathered floor-length skirts and kimono jackets, accented with gold fabric, fur and hand-appliqued lace. He collaborates on shoes with Manolo Blahnik. Bergdorf Goodman and Neiman Marcus carry his clothes.

name: Nikolai "Niki" Haas, Simon Haas
description: Furniture designers, Haas Brothers. Raised in Austin, TX by a stone carver father, the twins came to furniture design by way of music. Simon studied art and architecture at RISD, before dropping out to join Nikolai and play in an L.A. band. Then they started making furniture, including couches covered in Icelandic reindeer fur with gold hoof-like feet. Peter Marino commissioned them to design a bar made of gold leaf bricks for a Louis Vuitton store in Shanghai. For Lady Gaga they created black polyethylene masks and for Versace a

name: Colin P. Kelly
description: Industrial designer, Redscout. Designed the elegantly simple $30 TOT booster seat for OXO that folds up for easy carrying and the TOT Sprout chair, that grows along with the child from 5 months to 6 years old. Also works on brand strategy and early-stage designs for everything from beauty products to cars. Other clients include PepsiCo, Target, Unilever. Won a slew of design awards including the IDSA gold.

name: Aimee Kestenberg
description: Handbag designer. Launched line of colorful leather handbags and backpacks in 2012. The company grossed $10 million in its first year. Revenues are set to double in 2013. Her bags are sold on her own site and at Nordstrom, Macy's, Shopbop.com, QVC and boutiques in more than a half dozen countries including Japan and Mexico. She's gotten a flood of press, from Real Simple to Vogue. Plans to expand into shoes, belts and clothes in 2014.

name: Jemima Kirke
description: Painter-actress. British-born Kirke has become famous playing the sexually adventurous party girl Jessa on the HBO series Girls. In real life she is an accomplished painter of expressionist portraits, who has had one-woman shows in Brooklyn and New York and group shows in London and Miami.

name: Becca McCharen
description: Fashion designer, Chromat. Fashion designer who makes sexy pieces using straps and braces, worn by Beyonce, Madonna, Nicki Minaj and Jessica Chastain. Featured in Elle, Vogue Italia, Details, WWD. McCharen founded the company in 2010. It is profitable and in the first half of 2013, her revenues of $280,000 had doubled 2012 sales. She expects sales of $800,000 in 2014.

name: Leandra Medine
description: Fashion blogger, The Man Repeller. Medine launched her blog in 2010 as a 21-year-old journalism student living with her parents on Manhattan's Upper East Side. Three years later, The Man Repeller bags millions of page views a month, and the concept of "man repelling"--or fashion the opposite sex doesn't get--has entered the fashion vernacular, as has "arm party," a term she coined to describe her habit of stacking her forearms with numerous bracelets. This year she published a book called "Man Repeller: Seeking Love. Finding Over

name: Shauna Miller
description: Fashion Blogger, Penny Chic. In 2010 Miller founded Penny Chic, a fashion blog featuring looks styled from clothes and accessories available at discount stores like Walmart, Forever 21 and JCPenney. She designed a 2013 collection for Walmart.com of made-in-America $20 little black dresses for every occasion; the first shipment sold out in one month. She has a deal with Little, Brown to publish a style book for teens and tweens.

name: Oscar Murillo
description: Artist. Before Murillo went to art school he was working odd hours as a cleaner in a London office building so he could have time to make art. Now his paintings fetch as much as $400,000 at auction and he shows with major gallery David Zwirner. His work spans performance, installation, painting, sculpture. His big canvases with graffiti-like scribbles and his big prices have prompted some to call him the next Basquiat.

name: Victo Ngai
description: Illustrator. Hong Kong-born Ngai does intricate, colorful editorial illustrations for a long list of clients including The New Yorker, The New York Times, Wired, McDonald's, Scientific American. She has won a slew of awards including two gold medals from the Society of Illustrators. One drawing for The New Yorker shows a full page of interlocking mayfly wings in vivid yellows, oranges and browns.

name: Lotta Nieminen
description: Graphic designer. Finnish-born Nieminen worked for fashion magazine Trendi, for Pentagram Design and RoAndCo Studio. Now an independent designer, her clients include The New York Times, Volkswagen, United Airlines, Newsweek. For fashion house Hermès, she designed brightly colored window display graphics that included images of a scuba diver, submarine and octopus. Her awards include the Art Directors Club Young Guns.

name: Aaron Poritz
description: Furniture designer. While visiting a friend in Nicaragua, Poritz stumbled on a supply of beautiful old growth wood uprooted by Hurricane Felix. Trained as an architect, he used the wood to create a line of furniture inspired by the minimalism and simplicity of Bauhaus designers like Marcel Breuer. His stools, chairs, tables, beds, sofas have no screws; they are fixed by unique joinery designed by Poritz.

name: Eric Singer
description: Eyewear designer, Shwood. While working in a movie theater, Singer made sunglasses using orange-colored Madrone branches and thrift store lenses. He met four guys who liked the glasses and became Singer's partners, selling through a makeshift website. The glasses caught on. Shwood launched in 2009 and now employs 50 people in Portland, OR. The glasses sell for as much as $350 online and in 300 stores worldwide including Nordstrom, Bloomingdales, Saks.

name: Travess Smalley
description: Digital artist. West Virginia-born Smalley blends computer graphics with physical collage-making. His colorful pieces look like a cross between a painting and a screen saver. One piece has Rothko-like stripes in blues, greens and yellows, with what appear to be cut-outs layered on top. He has had solo shows in New York, Toronto and Milan.

name: Lucien Smith
description: Artist. Smith makes canvases with layered oil paint and detritus like newspaper and aluminum pie plates. One painting shows a hazy seascape. Another piece: silk screens of indexes from biology textbooks, covered in plexiglass. He has also displayed found brooms meant to signify the sweeping gentrification in New York. Has shown in New York, L.A., Miami, Milan, London.

name: Danielle Snyder
description: Jewelry designer, Dannijo. Together with sister Jodie Snyder, 31, Florida native started making jewelry in middle school using her cardiologist father's medical tools. Has also run a non-profit that fundraises for grassroots projects in Africa. All the packaging for Dannijo is made by women in Rwanda. The jewelry line features bib necklaces of oxidized metals, stones like turquoise and carnelian, pieces of crystal, and vintage glass beads. Worn by Oprah, Beyonce, Madonna, Rihanna, Natalie Portman.

name: Tanya Taylor
description: Fashion designer. Canada native Taylor hand-paints the prints for the fabrics in her quirky ready-to-wear collections of skirts, tops, frocks, pantsuits and jackets. She also uses stripes, plaids, mauve leather and pink fur. Sold at Saks Fifth Avenue.

name: Torey Thornton
description: Artist. Macon, GA-born Thornton makes figurative, colorful, crude still lifes with acrylic, oil, glued collage and graphite. Other artists collect his work. He has had a one-man show in New York and group shows in New York and London. OHWOW gallery in Los Angeles recently started representing him and plans are in the works for a debut show.

name: Jacob Willis
description: Fashion designer, Second/Layer. Along with his brother Joshua and childhood friend, Anthony Franco, Jacob creates androgynous minimalist clothing designed and made in Los Angeles. They call their finely tailored day wear "Chicano Minimal."
